metadata.case_name: Dhian Singh v. Municipal Board, Saharanpur

facts.text: Accused is proprietor of Khalsa Tea Stall situated in Court Road, Saharanpur, selling coloured sweets.
Food Inspector, Municipal Board, Saharanpur purchased coloured sweets (Patisa prepared in Vanaspati) from accused for examination under a Yaddasht on May 31, 1963.
Portion of sample sent to Public Analyst, Government of U.P.; received on June 4, 1963.

Public Analyst report No. 11652 dated June 24, 1963: Test for coal-tar dye positive; identified as Metanil yellow (Colour Index No. 138), not permitted under Rule 28 of Prevention of Food Adulteration Rules, 1955. Analytical data: Butyro-refractometer reading 50.5 at 40°C, melting point 33.8°C, Baudouin's test positive for Til oil, tintometer reading 4.0 Red + 0.1 Yellow.
Complaint filed in Court of City Magistrate, Saharanpur under s.7 read with s.16 of Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954, purportedly by Municipal Board, Saharanpur but signed by Food Inspector.
Accused pleaded not guilty; trial court acquitted on grounds: analyst report lacks data, Yaddasht not attested as required by law, seizure invalid.
Municipal Board appealed to Allahabad High Court under s.417(3) Cr.P.C. in Criminal Appeal No. 1642 of 1964.

High Court allowed appeal on April 18, 1966: analyst report contains necessary data; lack of attestation of Yaddasht does not vitiate seizure. Convicted accused, sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for 2 months and fine of Rs.100/- (default 1 month further imprisonment). No objection to maintainability at hearing.
Accused applied for certificate under Art.134 Constitution on April 28, 1966.

On May 4, 1966, accused moved High Court under s.561A Cr.P.C. for review, contending appeal not maintainable as complaint by Food Inspector, not Board. Dismissed March 16, 1967: complaint by Board, no power to review. Certificate under Art.134 refused same date.
Special leave obtained; appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appeal filed by Municipal Board before High Court under s.417(3) Cr.P.C. was maintainable, as complaint was signed by Food Inspector though purporting to be by Board.
Whether accused could be convicted on strength of Public Analyst's certificate, which allegedly lacks data.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appeal by Municipal Board under s.417(3) Cr.P.C. not maintainable as complaint instituted by Food Inspector, not complainant (Board); special leave only to complainant.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.417(3) Cr.P.C.; s.20 Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954

petitioner_arguments.text: Permission under s.20 PFA Act is condition precedent; must be proved; akin to sanction requiring application of mind.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.20 PFA Act; Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King; Madan Mohan Singh v. State of U.P.

petitioner_arguments.text: Analyst report lacks data on basis of conclusion; cannot form basis for conviction.

respondent_arguments.text: Complaint purports to be by Municipal Board; Food Inspector authorized under s.20 PFA Act to file on behalf.
No objection to maintainability raised earlier; parties proceeded on basis complaint validly instituted by Board.

court_reasoning.text: s.417(3) Cr.P.C. allows special leave to complainant; Municipal Board is complainant as per complaint; Food Inspector signed on its behalf, authorized under s.20 PFA Act as local authority.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No dispute Municipal Board is local authority; competent to authorize Food Inspector. No challenge to authority earlier; official acts deemed regular.

court_reasoning.text: Question of Food Inspector's authority is factual; not raised before trial court or High Court appeal; cannot raise post-appeal disposal. Complaint valid per K.C. Aggarwal v. Delhi Administration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If unauthorized, complaint itself invalid; never accused's case.

court_reasoning.text: s.20 PFA Act authorizes local authority to institute prosecutions or delegate; no need to apply mind to specific facts pre-offence, unlike sanction cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes Gokulchand and Madan Mohan as inapplicable.

court_reasoning.text: Analyst report contains data on which conclusion based; not incorrect to say it lacks data.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Report affords sufficient basis for conviction.

holdings.text: Appeal by Municipal Board under s.417(3) Cr.P.C. maintainable; complaint instituted by Board via authorized Food Inspector.
Public Analyst's report provides valid basis for conviction as it contains necessary data.

precedents_cited.citation: Criminal Appeal No. 100 of 1966, decided 27th May, 1969
precedents_cited.relevance: Complaint filed by officer of local authority at its instance is complaint by local authority.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mangaldas Raghavji v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Court refused to entertain objection to sanction validity first time after disposal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gokulchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Sanction requires application of mind; inapplicable to s.20 PFA Act authorization.

precedents_cited.case_name: Madan Mohan Singh v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Sanction requires proof of relevant facts placed before authority; inapplicable here.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for complaint and prosecution; s.20 limits institution to specified authorities or delegates.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Food Adulteration Rules, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Rule 28 lists permitted coal-tar dyes; Metanil yellow not permitted.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: s.417(3) for appeal against acquittal by complainant; s.561A for review.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected both contentions of appellant; upheld High Court judgment convicting accused under Prevention of Food Adulteration Act.

key_quotes.text: "Section 417(3) of the Criminal Procedure Code provides that if an order of acquittal is passed in any case instituted upon complaint, the High Court may grant to the complainant special leave to appeal against the order of acquittal."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Official acts must be deemed to have been done according to law."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Under s.20 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954, no question of applying ones mind to the facts of the case before the institution of the complaint arises."
key_quotes.speaker: court
